newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Outback Australia pays more for petrol-Ampol.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Outback Australia pays more for petrol-Ampol.

text.p: Australia's largest petrol (gasoline) retailer, Australian Petroleum Pty Ltd (Ampol) said on Monday that Australians living in rural areas on average paid up to 7.8 cents a litre more for petrol than those living in cities.
"Outback areas often have high freight costs, but high prices in less remote country towns are usually the result of high retail margins," Ampol managing director Ian Blackburne said in a statement.
A survey by Ampol shows Western Australia recorded the highest discrepancy in average city and rural prices in February of 7.8 cents a litre.
South Australia was second, with city drivers paying on average 6.8 cents a litre less.
In Queensland, rural prices were 5.3 cents higher while in Victoria they were 4.2 cents higher, Ampol said.
Australia's most populated state, New South Wales, showed a difference of 4.6 cents a litre, Ampol said.
The Northern Territory and Tasmania state, two of the least populated regions of Australia, recorded the smallest discrepancies of 2.1 cents and 1.2 cents respectively, Ampol said.
Ampol owns or leases about 1,200 retail service stations in Australia. It is owned 50 percent by Caltex Australia Ltd and Pioneer International Ltd
